fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The morphisms of filtered complexes ( \Omega _X^ \bullet \langle Y \rangle , W) \xleftarrow { \alpha } ( \Omega _X^ \bullet \langle Y \rangle , \tau ) \xhookrightarrow { \beta } (j_* \Omega _{X^*}^ \bullet , \tau ) are filtered quasi-isomorphisms. They define an isomorphism between the Leray spectral sequence for j in complex cohomology and the hypercohomology spectral sequence of the filtered complex ( \Omega _X^ \bullet \langle Y \rangle , W) on X.

By and , it suffices to prove the first claim. In [D1970, II, (6.9)] or [AH1955], one can find a proof of the fact that \beta is a quasi-isomorphism, and thus a filtered quasi-isomorphism. We can also directly calculate the cohomology sheaves of the two sides: those of \Omega _X^ \bullet \langle Y \rangle are determined by [hodge-theory-ii-3.1.5.2 (?)], while those of j_* \Omega _{X^*}^ \bullet are the \mathrm {R} ^ij_* \mathbb {C}, which can be calculated by topological methods.

By and , it suffices to prove the first claim. In [D1970, II, (6.9)] or [AH1955], one can find a proof of the fact that \beta is a quasi-isomorphism, and thus a filtered quasi-isomorphism. We can also directly calculate the cohomology sheaves of the two sides: those of \Omega _X^ \bullet \langle Y \rangle are determined by [hodge-theory-ii-3.1.5.2 (?)], while those of j_* \Omega _{X^*}^ \bullet are the \mathrm {R} ^ij_* \mathbb {C}, which can be calculated by topological methods.
